right not so fast there are lots of
problems with running for president as

an independent which probably explains
why we haven't had an independent

president yet and why Schulz is unlikely
to break that forever trend let's go

through the problems problem number one
the two parties are super powerful did

you know every state has a different

that most of those states require you to

collect lots and lots of signatures from
people who live in them and that

collecting tens of thousands of

very very expensive but when you're the

president the long-standing party

independent

not so much problem number two there are
fewer actual independents out there than

you might think
now remember all those numbers I cited

Republicans yeah they're basically bunk
nextly they're not totally bunk just not

totally accurate when it comes to who

tell pollsters that their independence

because it fits with how they see

make a recent assessment of which

about so-called independence is that
most of them are closeted partisans yeah

they like to tell pollsters and people
like cocktail parties that they don't

side with one party but when they vote
they consistently vote for one side over

the other problem number three you have
to convince people you aren't just a

likely to run for president as an
independent reveals this Democrats

really and I mean really don't want him
to do it the argument goes that Schulz

all lifetime Democrat will sap votes
from the Democratic nominee and lower

Trump's win number in a two way race
Trump needs fifty percent of the vote

plus one which most polls suggest he
will struggle to come anywhere close to

in a 3-way race however Trump could win
somewhere between 42 percent and 47

percent depending on how credible
Schultz remains in the race the other

less partisan problem with the whole
spoiler thing is that the average voter

doesn't like to feel like they are
throwing their vote away on someone who

has zero chance of winning there's a
long history of independent candidates

running in the mid teens in terms of
support a few months before the election

and then watching that support totally
collapse as the election gets closer and

people think twice about casting what
amounts to a protest vote of course none

of this means Schultz won't run I mean
he's running unless something huge and

unforeseen happens and none of it means
that he can't be a real factor in the

race especially if Democrats choose
someone regarded as too far to the

ideological left of the average swing
voter what all of it means though is

this running as an independent for
president and wanting to actually have a

chance to win is a hell of a lot harder
than it looks from a quick analysis of

our country's politics
